main.java.embl.rieslab.emu.ui.uiproperties

Class UIProperty

  • java.lang.Object
    • main.java.embl.rieslab.emu.ui.uiproperties.UIProperty
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    ImmutableMultiStateUIProperty, MultiStateUIProperty, SingleStateUIProperty, TwoStateUIProperty

    public class UIProperty
extends java.lang.Object
    A UIProperty object is aimed at linking a user interface action with a MMProperty from Micro-Manager. It should be instantiated in the initializeProperties() implementation of a ConfigurablePanel subclass and add using the addUIProperty() method of ConfigurablePanels.

    If correctly instantiated and added to the ConfigurablePanel, the UIProperty will appear in the configuration wizard of EMU. The user can then assign a MMproperty to this UIProperty. While several UIProperties can listen to a single MMProperty, each UIPropoerty can only be assigned to a single MMproperty. In the configuration wizard, the label of the UIProperty will appear as well as the description in the help window if the help is enabled.

    If a UI action should change the value of UIProperty (meaning the value of its MMProperty), then the ConfigurablePanel calls setPropertyValue(String). In turns, this will change the value of the MMProperty and trigger a call to mmPropertyHasChanged(String) in the other UIProperties listening to the same MMProperty. Finally, updated UIProperty will call the owner ConfigurablePanel (triggerPropertyHasChanged()) to change the relevant JComponents.

    UIProperties can be labeled with a PropertyFlag to allow categorizing them. This mechanism is not used within EMU, but can be used by its plugins.

    Several extensions of UIProperty exist and have additional properties: 

     - TwoStateUIProperty accepts only two states, ON and OFF, whose values are not known at compilation time and can be set in the configuration wizard.
 - MultiStateUIProperty accepts multiple states. While the values of the states are also not know at compilation time, the number of states is fixed during
 instantiation.
 - SingleStateUIProperty accepts a single state, unknown at compilation time.
 - ImmutableMultiStateUIProperty accepts multiple states that are fixed at instantiation.
    Author:
    Joran Deschamps

    • Property Detail

      • isConfigGroupMM

        Checks if the assigned MMProperty is a Configuration group from Micro-manager.
        Returns:
        True if it is, false otherwise or if the UIProperty is not assigned.

      • getLabel

        public java.lang.String getLabel()
        Returns the UIProperty's label
        Returns:
        Label of the UIProperty

      • getDescription

        public java.lang.String getDescription()
        Returns the UIProperty's description, this description is used in the Help window of the configuration wizard.
        Returns:
        Description of the UIProperty

      • assignProperty

        public void assignProperty(MMProperty prop)
                    throws AlreadyAssignedUIPropertyException
        Assigns the UIProperty to a MMProperty. A UIProperty can only be assigned once and to a single MMProperty. This method will throw an AlreadyAssignedUIPropertyException if there is an attempt to assign it to a second MMProperty.
        Parameters:
        prop - MMproperty to assign the UIProperty to
        Throws:
        AlreadyAssignedUIPropertyException - Exception thrown when the UIproperty has already been assigned

      • isAssigned

        public boolean isAssigned()
        Checks if the UIProperty has been assigned or not.
        Returns:
        True if the UIProperty is assigned to a MMProperty, false otherwise.

      • mmPropertyHasChanged

        public void mmPropertyHasChanged(java.lang.String value)
        Notifies its ConfigurablePanel owner that the MMProperty it is assigned to has changed its value.
        Parameters:
        value - New value of the MMProperty

      • getPropertyValue

        public java.lang.String getPropertyValue()
        Returns the value of the MMProperty it is assigned to.
        Returns:
        Value of the MMProperty or an empty String if the UIProperty has not been assigned to a MMProperty

      • setPropertyValue

        public void setPropertyValue(java.lang.String newValue)
        Sets the value of the assigned MMProperty ot newValue.
        Parameters:
        newValue - New value

      • getMMProperty

        protected MMProperty getMMProperty()
        Returns the assigned MMProperty.
        Returns:
        The assigned MMProperty, null if the UIProperty has not been assigned

      • getFriendlyName

        public java.lang.String getFriendlyName()
        Returns the UIProperty's friendly name.
        Returns:
        Friendly name, or the UIProperty's label if the friendly name is null

      • setFriendlyName

        public void setFriendlyName(java.lang.String newFriendlyName)
        Sets the UIProperty's friendly name.
        Parameters:
        newFriendlyName - New friendly name

      • isMMPropertyReadOnly

        public boolean isMMPropertyReadOnly()
        Checks if the MMProperty assigned to this UIProperty is read-only.
        Returns:
        True if the MMProperty is read-only, false otherwise. If the UIProperty is not assigned, returns true.

      • hasMMPropertyAllowedValues

        public boolean hasMMPropertyAllowedValues()
        Checks if the MMProperty assigned to this UIProperty has allowed values.
        Returns:
        True if it does, false otherwise. If the UIProperty is not assigned, then returns false.

      • hasMMPropertyLimits

        public boolean hasMMPropertyLimits()
        Checks if the MMProperty assigned to this UIProperty has limits.
        Returns:
        True if it does, false otherwise. If the UIProperty is not assigned, then returns false.

      • getAllowedValues

        public java.lang.String[] getAllowedValues()
        Returns the allowed values of the assigned MMProperty.
        Returns:
        Allowed values or null if the MMProperty does not have any or if the UIProperty is not assigned.

      • getLimits

        public java.lang.String[] getLimits()
        Returns the limits of the assigned MMProperty.
        Returns:
        Limits or null if the MMProperty does not have any or if the UIProperty is not assigned.

      • getFlag

        public PropertyFlag getFlag()
        Returns the PropertyFlag of this UIProperty.
        Returns:
        PropertyFlag of the UIProperty

      • isValueAllowed

        public boolean isValueAllowed(java.lang.String val)
        Checks if the String val is an allowed value for the MMProperty.
        Parameters:
        val - Value to test
        Returns:
        True if the value is allowed, false otherwise. If the UIProperty is not assigned, returns true

      • isConfigGroupMMProperty

        public boolean isConfigGroupMMProperty()
        Checks if the assigned MMProperty is a Configuration group from Micro-manager.
        Returns:
        True if it is, false otherwise or if the UIProperty is not assigned.
